document.masterDocTitle: Rearrangements in some species groups of Amblycerus Thunberg, 1815 (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae: Bruchinae) including keys, description of a new species, new host plant and distributional records

(desc., distr., gen., type ).

Amblycerus crassipunctatus
\ Ribeiro-Costa, 1999.
Measurements . Holotype , BL: 9.6 mm; BW: 5.2 mm

Diagnosis ( Figs 22 , 61–62, 91, 97)
.
Amblycerus crassipunctatus
is distinguished mainly by the eyes distant from each other anteriorly, ocular index: 3.5 ( Fig. 22 ) and median lobe of male genitalia about 3.7 times as long as its greatest width at apical region ( Figs 91 , 97 ); internal sac in the apical region with one pair of subtriangular sclerites with lateral margins serrated ( Fig. 91 ).
Amblycerus crassipunctatus
can be separated from
A. schwarzi
by having the cervical boss with three setae (two setae in
A. schwarzi
), hind tibia with lateral spur about 2.0 times the length of median spur (about 3.0 times in
A. schwarzi
) and ventrite V almost as long as ventrite IV (ventrite V almost two times as long as the ventrite IV).
Amblycerus crassipunctatus
can be further separated from
A. dispar
by the frontal carina absent (present in
A. dispar
), eyes distant from each other anteriorly ( Fig. 22 ) (closer in
A. dispar
) and metaventrite with median sulcus about half the length of metaventrite (longer than half length of metaventrite in
A. dispar
).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution ( Fig. 117 )
. Venezuela and Brazil (Pará, Mato Grosso , Distrito Federal, Minas Gerais ).

Life History . According to
Johnson et al . (2001)
,
A. crassipunctatus
belongs to Johnson’s (1981) Guild A, since the female oviposits on the surface of fruits of
Vantanea minor Bentham
( Humiriaceae ), its unique seed predator. The eggs have a flange with glue on the periphery, similar to that is found in other
Amblycerus
spp. (i.e.
A. vitis
,
A. submaculatus ( Pic, 1927 )
,
A. dispar
,
A. longesuturalis ( Pic, 1954 )
and
A. robiniae ( Fabricius, 1781 )
.
Johnson et al . (2001)
recorded 28.5% and 39% of
V. minor
fruits damaged by
A. crassipunctatus
; in other
Amblycerus
species from 01.0% to 61% of the fruits were damage.

Host plant (Tab. II) .
Humiriaceae
:
Vantanea minor Benth.
